original_data.question: A 62-year-old woman with small-cell lung cancer comes to the physician because of a painful, burning red rash on her face and hands that developed 30 minutes after going outside to do garden work. She wore a long-sleeved shirt and was exposed to direct sunlight for about 10 minutes. The patient is light-skinned and has a history of occasional sunburns when she does not apply sunscreen. Current medications include demeclocycline for malignancy-associated hyponatremia and amoxicillin for sinusitis. Physical examination shows prominent erythema and a papular eruption on her forehead, cheeks, neck, and the dorsum of both hands. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

options.D: Cell injury due to drug metabolites

model_response:
This patient's symptoms are most consistent with a diagnosis of phototoxicity. Phototoxicity occurs when a drug or other chemical agent (in this case, demeclocycline) is absorbed into the skin and is photoactivated by exposure to sunlight or a tanning lamp. The activated drug can cause cell injury, resulting in erythema, edema, pruritus, and, in severe cases, vesicle formation and bullae. Mast cell degranulation and immune complex formation would be expected with allergic or hyper- sensitivity reactions, respectively. Porphyria and drug-induced autoantibodies are not associated with these findings.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
A form of highly malignant lung cancer that is composed of small ovoid cells (SMALL CELL CARCINOMA).
Having a black or dark core or plug.
Individuals licensed to practice medicine.
An unpleasant sensation induced by noxious stimuli which are detected by NERVE ENDINGS of NOCICEPTIVE NEURONS.
The anterior portion of the head that includes the skin, muscles, and structures of the forehead, eyes, nose, mouth, cheeks, and jaw.
The distal part of the arm beyond the wrist in humans and primates, that includes the palm, fingers, and thumb.
Cultivation of PLANTS; (FRUIT; VEGETABLES; MEDICINAL HERBS) on small plots of ground or in containers.
The act of subjecting someone or something to an influencing experience.
A unit measure of time equal to 60 seconds.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
Record and study of past events.
Not occurring regularly or at short intervals.
An injury to the skin causing erythema, tenderness, and sometimes blistering and resulting from excessive exposure to the sun. The reaction is produced by the ultraviolet radiation in sunlight.
Drugs intended for human or veterinary use, presented in their finished dosage form. Included here are materials used in the preparation and/or formulation of the finished dosage form.
A TETRACYCLINE analog having a 7-chloro and a 6-methyl. Because it is excreted more slowly than tetracycline, it maintains effective blood levels for longer periods of time.
A broad-spectrum semisynthetic antibiotic similar to AMPICILLIN except that its resistance to gastric acid permits higher serum levels with oral administration.
Inflammation of the NASAL MUCOSA in one or more of the PARANASAL SINUSES.
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Redness of the skin produced by congestion of the capillaries. This condition may result from a variety of disease processes.
A small (less than 5-10 mm) elevation of skin that is non-suppurative.
The part of the face above the eyes.
The part of the face that is below the eye and to the side of the nose and mouth.
The part of a human or animal body connecting the HEAD to the rest of the body.
The rear surface of an upright primate from the shoulders to the hip, or the dorsal surface of tetrapods.
The distal part of the arm beyond the wrist in humans and primates, that includes the palm, fingers, and thumb.

Fundamental claims of patients, as expressed in statutes, declarations, or generally accepted moral principles. (Bioethics Thesaurus) The term is used for discussions of patient rights as a group of many rights, as in a hospital's posting of a list of patient rights.
